title: [aerospace] High Employee Turnover Risk in Operations
description: The Operations department has the highest number of employees (14), but the distribution of salary grades shows a significant number of employees at lower grades (G06 and G05). This may indicate potential dissatisfaction and a risk of turnover.
recommendations: Review compensation packages for competitive alignment
business_impact: High turnover can lead to operational disruptions and increased training costs.

title: [aerospace] Concentration Risk in Baggage Handling
description: All baggage handling records indicate that bags are consistently checked in as 'CHECKED' and have a single origin (ICN). This concentration could lead to vulnerabilities if there are disruptions at this hub.
recommendations: Diversify baggage handling processes across multiple origins
Develop contingency plans for disruptions at ICN
business_impact: A disruption at the primary origin could lead to significant operational delays and customer dissatisfaction.

title: [aerospace] Frequent Delays with Minimal Impact
description: The average delay minutes are relatively low (10.49), with most delays categorized as MINIMAL. However, the estimated costs associated with these delays can accumulate, suggesting a need for better delay management.
recommendations: Analyze root causes of delays to improve scheduling
business_impact: While individual delays are minor, cumulative effects can impact customer satisfaction and operational efficiency.

title: [aerospace] High Parts Cost in Aircraft Maintenance
description: The average parts cost for aircraft maintenance is $6,965, with a maximum of $125,000. This suggests potential inefficiencies or reliance on expensive parts, which could impact overall maintenance budgets.
recommendations: Negotiate bulk purchasing agreements with suppliers
business_impact: Reducing parts costs can significantly improve maintenance budgets and overall profitability.

title: [aerospace] High Employee Turnover Risk in Operations

title: [aerospace] Concentration of Maintenance Work on Specific Aircraft Types
description: The majority of maintenance work is concentrated on a few aircraft types, notably the B737-800 and A321. This could lead to operational risks if these aircraft experience issues or require extensive downtime.
recommendations: Diversify maintenance schedules across different aircraft types
Invest in additional aircraft types to reduce reliance
business_impact: Over-reliance on specific aircraft can lead to operational bottlenecks and increased maintenance costs.

title: [aerospace] Frequent Delays with Minimal Compensation
description: The average delay time is 10.49 minutes, with a significant number of delays categorized as 'MINIMAL'. However, the average passenger compensation is only 0.04, indicating a potential gap in customer service and satisfaction.
recommendations: Enhance communication with passengers during delays
business_impact: Poor handling of delays can damage airline reputation and customer loyalty.

title: [aerospace] High Parts Cost Variability in Maintenance
description: The parts cost for maintenance has a wide range, with a maximum of $125,000. This variability could indicate inefficiencies in procurement or unexpected repairs.
business_impact: High parts costs can significantly impact overall maintenance budgets and profitability.

title: [aerospace] Underutilization of Badge Access Levels
description: There is a significant concentration of employees with badge access level 2 (25 employees) compared to level 1 (7 employees). This may indicate an imbalance in access control that could pose security risks.
recommendations: Ensure proper training and security protocols are in place
business_impact: Improper access control can lead to security breaches and operational disruptions.
